1. A physicist who worked in this city named a society whose "left wing" attempted to apply its "scientific world-conception" to all aspects of life. A philosopher who worked in this city wrote The Logical Structure of the World and argued for the "elimination of metaphysics" as part of the verificationist program. The logical positivist Rudolf Carnap was part of an empiricist (*) "circle" of philosophers from this city. A posthumously published book by a Cambridge professor born in this capital city developed the theory of "language games," contradicting the "picture theory of meaning" from his earlier Tractatus. For 10 points, name this capital city, the birthplace of the author of Philosophical Investigations, Ludwig Wittgenstein.
ANSWER: Vienna [or Wien; accept Vienna Circle or Wiener Kreis] (The first clue refers to the Ernst Mach Society, to which much of the Vienna Circle belonged.)
<Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~29772~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

ANSWER: Vienna [or Wien; accept Vienna Circle or Wiener Kreis] (The first clue refers to the Ernst Mach Society, to which much of the Vienna Circle belonged.) <Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~29772~ <Editor: Aum Mundhe>

2. Edward Morse's excavation of a mound of these objects at Omori kick-started Japanese archaeology. They're not pebbles, but these objects were tied to wood to represent islands on Polynesian stick charts. The word "porcelain" comes from an Italian word for these objects. Imported examples of these objects devalued the nzimbu ones harvested from Luanda for use by the Kingdom of Kongo. These objects were thrown to the ground in a West African tradition for (*) divination. Native Americans made wampum beads from these objects. The Classical Chinese character for "money" was an image of these objects, which were harvested in the Indian Ocean from cowries. For 10 points, name these hard objects harvested from clams and conches.
ANSWER: shells [accept seashells; accept cowrie shells; accept clamshells or channeled whelk shells; accept Omori Shell Mound]
<Rohan Kher, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~30105~ <Editor: Michael Bentley>

3. Jean-Pierre Serre's epsilon conjecture connected work by this mathematician to a 1957 conjecture via an object named for Gerhard Frey. A non-conjectural statement named for Goldbach gives the coprimality of numbers named for this mathematician. A primality test that relies on a statement given by this mathematician fails on Carmichael numbers, which are this mathematician's "pseudoprimes." (*) Euler's totient theorem generalizes a statement by this mathematician, who stated a conjecture that motivated the proof of the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture. This mathematician stated that a-to-the-p equals p mod p and was vindicated in 1995 by Andrew Wiles. For 10 points, name this mathematician with "little" and "last" theorems.
ANSWER: Pierre de Fermat (The epsilon conjecture gives that the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture implies Fermat's last theorem. Goldbach's theorem describes Fermat numbers.)
<Steven Yuan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30840~ <Editor: David Bass>

This mathematician stated that a-to-the-p equals p mod p and was vindicated in 1995 by Andrew Wiles.
For 10 points, name this mathematician with "little" and "last" theorems.
ANSWER: Pierre de Fermat (The epsilon conjecture gives that the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture implies Fermat's last theorem.
Goldbach's theorem describes Fermat numbers.) <Steven Yuan, Science - Math and Computer Science> ~30840~ <Editor: David Bass>

4. This modern-day country titles a highly geometric rendition of a Lancaster grain elevator by Charles Demuth. Edmonia Lewis depicted an ancient leader of this country dead on a throne. Some of the best surviving examples of Roman painting are funerary portraits on wooden boards in this country. Sculptures found in this country include a lifelike limestone of a seated (*) scribe and several of rulers stiffly walking with their fists clenched. Several artists painted landscapes with the Holy Family's "flight" into this country. Depictions of the ka decorate a tomb in this country where a gold and lapis lazuli death mask was discovered. For 10 points, name this home of the Mask of Tutankhamun.
ANSWER: Egypt [or Arab Republic of Egypt; accept Ancient Egypt; accept My Egypt; accept the Flight from Egypt]

5. One of this language's "three classics" authors wrote a story in which a heavenly court reviews the sufferings of a man dubbed "the Silent." An author whose pen name came from this language's phrase for "peace be upon you" created a protagonist who "blows a small fortune" after two women pay him to take them through a forest on his wagon. In a story in this language, a man learns from his dying wife that their children all resulted from affairs shortly before the Spirit of Evil tells him to (*) urinate into his dough. The Tevye ("TEV-yuh") the Dairyman stories and "Gimpel the Fool" were written in this language by Sholem Aleichem ("SHOH-lum ah-LAY-khum") and Isaac Bashevis Singer. For 10 points, what largely Germanic language is used by Ashkenazi Jews?
ANSWER: Yiddish [or yidish or idish] (The first line refers to "Bontshe the Silent" by I. L. Peretz.)

7. The rejection of less conventional examples of this action led Feeneyism to be declared heretical. One performance of this action inspired the use of the word yardna in Mandaeism. Dismas is often cited as an example of a Biblical figure undergoing one form of this action "of desire," while another form "of blood" was espoused by Cyprian of Carthage. The use of the (*) Trinitarian formula in this practice comes from Jesus ordering its performance in the Great Commission. A sect that stresses the importance of conscious belief before this sacrament and opposes its performance on infants is named for this practice prefixed with "Ana." For 10 points, name this sacrament performed on Jesus in the Jordan River.
ANSWER: baptism [accept word forms such as baptize or baptist; accept christening; accept baptism by blood or baptism of blood or baptism by desire or baptism of desire; accept infant baptism; accept Anabaptists; accept believer's baptism] (The term yardna derives from the Jordan River.)

8. Residents of this country conclude that a clock is a god because a man claims he seldom does anything without consulting it. People in this country are rewarded with red, green, or blue silks for skill in "leaping and creeping" around sticks. Rival factions in this country wear high or low heels to mark their affiliation and argue about whether (*) eggs should be broken at the big or little end. A man is charged with treason in this country for urinating to put out a fire. At the beginning of a novel, a man awakens after a shipwreck to find himself tied to the ground by the residents of this country, whose rival is Blefuscu. For 10 points, name this country of six-inch-tall people in Gulliver's Travels.

9. This person cared for the children of relatives William Smith and John Shaw because they were both alcoholics. In the 12 years as the sole head of the household, this person greatly expanded the Peacefield House. A stone monument named for this person marks the spot where she watched the Battle of Bunker Hill. This woman's (*) husband expressed fear of a "despotism of the petticoat" while participating in the First Continental Congress. In one of her many saved letters, this woman stated, "All men would be tyrants if they could," and urged, "Remember the ladies." This woman defended the Alien and Sedition Acts passed by her husband. For 10 points, name this second US First Lady.

10. This is the third word of a method that uses character tables to identify equivalent atoms and stretching modes, where this word follows "symmetry adapted." This is the first word of a technique that uses the Hartree-Fock method to compute coefficients for the sum of a basis set of Gaussian or Slater-type orbitals. Molecular orbitals can be formed by a (*) combination of atomic orbitals described by this word. Molecules described by this six-letter word have 3N minus 5 vibrational degrees of freedom. Since it has three lone pairs and two bonds, tri·iodide has this molecular geometry. Carbon dioxide also has this geometry. For 10 points, name this geometry of molecules with a 180 degree bond angle.
ANSWER: linear [accept symmetry adapted linear combinations or linear rotors or linear combination of atomic orbitals]

11. This author claims he would kiss the skin between the lower part of a woman's shoulder and the upper part of her arm if it were exposed. This author, who exclaims, "perhaps...my writings will not be given to the Lethe's waters," later invokes Phoebus and nine goddesses to grant that wish in the third book of one of his works. In that work, this author said that "as Chiron was to Achilles, I am to (*) Cupid". This author of Remedia Amoris structured one work as a long poem that progressed from the creation of the world to the deification of Julius Caesar. After a supposed "poem and an error" caused his exile to Tomis, this author wrote Tristia. For 10 points, name this Roman author of Ars Amatoria and Metamorphoses.
ANSWER: Ovid [or Publius Ovidius Naso]

12. It's not chickens, but some Robert Fantz experiments on these subjects involved a "looking chamber." These subjects less frequently fail the Three Mountains task when three-dimensional models are used. To evaluate a semantogenic theory, Mary Tudor conducted the notorious Monster study of these subjects. These subjects are hesitant to move forward over a "visual (*) cliff." Researchers yelled "pow, boom" in front of these subjects to study their tendency to model aggression. Walter Mischel has lamented that one of his experiments on these people has been interpreted as implying that "your life is in a marshmallow." For 10 points, name these people whose progress through four stages, according to Jean Piaget.
ANSWER: children [or infants or babies or toddlers; accept orphans; accept kids or youths; accept teenagers after "semantogenic" is read; prompt on young people or humans before "people" is read; prompt on minors or juveniles]

13. Alicia de Larrocha made the first complete recording of a piece for this instrument that contrasts A-flat minor and A-flat major in its opening Evocación ("eh-vo-ca-see-OWN"). The song "Bésame Mucho" was inspired by "The Maiden and the Nightingale," a piece for this instrument from Enrique Granados' Goyescas. Ricardo Viñes premiered a piece for this instrument whose first movement depicts the Generalife ("he-ne-ra-LEE-feh"), Manuel de Falla's ("FA-ya's") (*) Nights in the Gardens of Spain. Basque folk music inspired a G major concerto for this instrument by Maurice Ravel that begins with a whip crack. Paul Wittgenstein premiered Ravel's concerto for the left hand on this instrument. For 10 points, the right pedal is used for sustain on what keyboard instrument?
ANSWER: piano [or pianoforte] (The piece in the first clue is Isaac Albeniz's Iberia.)
<Forrest Weintraub, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~29531~ <Editor: Forrest Weintraub>

14. In this modern-day country, a rebel leader was nicknamed "heavy thud" for his thunderous footfalls. To bolster his campaign, John F. Kennedy donated $100,000 to a Tom Mboya ("em-BOY-ah")-led program bringing students from this country to America. Rebels in this country were accused of leading blood-drinking rituals by Rawson Macharia during the 1952 trial of a group that included Kung'u Karumba and Bildad Kaggia, the (*) Kapenguria Six. Evelyn Baring authorized Operation Anvil during an anticolonial uprising in this country led by Dedan Kimathi. Jaramogi Oginga Odinga founded the KPU party in this country, which was rocked by the Mau Mau Rebellion. For 10 points, name this East African country led from Nairobi.
